intro: Maharanga sinica var. farreri, commonly known as the Chinese maharanga, is a rare and ornamental plant native to southern China. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae and is characterized by its striking, palmate leaves that resemble a hand. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in late spring, adding a subtle visual interest. It thrives in moist, well-drained soil and prefers partial to full shade, making it suitable for woodland gardens. Due to its rarity and unique appearance, it is often cultivated by botanists and plant enthusiasts.
